name: Pop-Free CB 10 Quiz | Common Bond 10 Questions | 10 Questions

questions.text: His opponents estimate that during President George Bush's tenure from 2000-2004, about 2 million of these disappeared in the US.
questions.explanation:
Jobs.

	As Sydney H. Schanberg wrote in "The Village Voice," "Most of the [tax] cuts go to the richest of Americans. Bush's theory is that these are the nation's entrepreneurs who will use the bulk of their windfall to create new jobs. But we've lost jobs instead - more than 2 million of them since George Bush took office. He doesn't seem to have noticed."

questions.text: Supposedly, this scientist's beloved dog Diamond accidentally caused a fire that destroyed years of research papers.
questions.explanation:
Newton.

	Supposedly, after the accident, Newton exclaimed something like, "Oh Diamond, you don't know what you've done," and life went on.

questions.text: In 1954, the first of these was built that did not rely upon vacuum tubes.
questions.explanation:
Computer.

	TRADIC, short for Transistorized Digital Computer, was built by Bell Labs.

questions.text: What is the largest wild cat in North America?
questions.explanation:
Jaguar.

	Jaguars are found in parts of Mexico, and occasionally even as far north as Texas. They often reach weights of well over 200 pounds.

questions.text: It's both a fruit and a raincoat. (Spelled slightly differently)
questions.explanation:
Macintosh.

	Macintosh is both a variety of apple (McIntosh) and a raincoat made of rubberized fabric.

questions.text: This Silicon Valley city is home to Symantec, among other corporations.
questions.explanation:
Cupertino.

	Cupertino also boasts many parks and golf courses.

questions.text: This text editor is loved by geeks everywhere, especially programmers.
questions.explanation:
Emacs.

	Emacs was invented at the Artificial Intelligence Laboratory at MIT in 1976. It is especially popular with users of Unix machines.

questions.text: Which of the following phrases is not grammatically correct?
questions.explanation:
Think different.

	As "think" is a verb, it needs to be followed by an adverb- in this case, "differently."

questions.text: In what year was Geraldine Ferraro the first woman from a major political party to run for Vice President of the United States?
questions.explanation:
1984.

	She was the running mate for Democratic contender Walter Mondale.

questions.text: So what topic do all of the above answers have in common?
questions.explanation:
Apple&Apple Computer&Apple Computers.

	Apple Computer, one of whose founders was Steve Jobs (Q. 1) is based in Cupertino, California (Q. 6.) It makes some of the most innovative computers (Q. 3) on the market, and is most well-known for the Macintosh (Q. 5) line. One model in this line, the eMac, (Q. 7) is a very popular machine in schools. The Newton (Q. 2) was Apple's early-90's venture into handheld computers- unfortunately, too early!Apple's operating software, OS 10.2, was codenamed "Jaguar" (Q. 4.) Apple has had many memorable advertising campaigns, including the "1984" (Q. 9) Super Bowl commercial that launched the first Mac, and the "Think Different" (Q. 8) campaign that featured innovative thinkers like Einstein and Cesar Chavez.
